Award.AwardTitle: RAPID: Collaborative Research: Evolution and variability of modern human sleep patterns

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
In this RAPID project, the investigators will measure melatonin levels and timing of sleep in two non-industrialized populations that are similar except for access to electricity, to understand how sleep is affected by artificial light and the interaction of artificial and natural light exposures. Because power lines are quickly being extended in the research area, this experimental design is possible during a limited window of time before electricity reaches all communities. The research will contribute to our understanding of underlying biological mechanisms and variability of human sleep patterns. The project will support student training, international research collaborations, and public and community science outreach activities, and has potential relevance for understanding sleep problems in industrialized settings.

The investigators will collect data on melatonin levels and sleep timing for individuals in each of two Toba/Qom communities. Participants will wear activity watches and keep diaries to document sleep patterns and quality. Saliva samples will be assayed to determine each individual's daily melatonin onset. The main predictions are that individuals in the community with artificial light will have a later time of daily melatonin onset, that differences will be greatest during the winter, and that any effect of moonlight would be to decrease sleep quality, more so in the population without artificial light. The project will expand our understanding of the spectrum of sleep patterns and sleep-regulatory pressures that may have played distinct roles in human history and evolution, and the ways in which modern societies have modified human sleep patterns.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Humans spend a third of their life sleeping. Yet, we have much to learn about how sleep patterns have changed during human evolution and, more recently, during the transition from hunting-gathering to agricultural to industrial societies. Our research study aims at understanding the changes in sleep after the introduction of artificial light in a population that did not have access to electricity in the past. Working with the indigenous Toba/Qom of Argentina, we are contributing behavioral and physiological data that allows us to describe the impact that access to electricity has on sleep/activity patterns and also on the master clock in our brain. Our preliminary results indicate, for example, that artificial light delays the phase of the circadian clock during the short days of winter and makes it more like the one seen during the long summer days. We are also interested in understanding the effect of moonlight on sleep patterns in communities with no access to electricity as a possible window into the lifestyle that was the most common during human evolution and that would have shaped our present sleep biology.

Findings from our research will contribute to the study of the mechanisms behind the choreography of sleep/activity patterns and, thus, shed light on important human evolutionary biology characteristics.  At the same time, it has important applied implications for sleep medicine and physiological regulation in general.

Our research program trains graduates, undergraduates and postdocs from both the US and Argentina. Trainees and collaborators include members of underrepresented minorities in STEM, including women, Latin@s, and indigenous peoples. This project is integrated within a network of synergistic anthropology projects that involve work with both the Toba/Qom in other communities and with non-human primates in the Gran Chaco. We also work in close collaboration with Fundacion ECO, a logal non-profit organization devoted to education in the regioh. Outreach activities are a constant feature of our work.
